name: HD 191939
scenarioDescription:
The HD 191939 Exoplanetary System

HD 191939 is a star with 0.92 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.94 times its radius. It is located 174.43 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 191939 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HD 191939 b

HD 191939 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-06. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.88 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 191939.

The mass of HD 191939 b is 18.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 191939 b is 3.42 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 191939 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

HD 191939 c

HD 191939 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-06. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 28.58 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 191939.

The mass of HD 191939 c is 16.02 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 191939 c is 3.23 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 191939 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

HD 191939 d

HD 191939 d was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-06. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 38.36 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 191939.

The mass of HD 191939 d is 15.23 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 191939 d is 3.16 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 191939 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 191939, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
